description: Wheat is a staple food crop grown worldwide, primarily for its grain, which is used to make flour for bread, pasta, and other products. It is cultivated in a wide range of climates, from temperate to subtropical regions, with varieties adapted to different growing conditions.

soil.type: Well-drained, loamy soils with good fertility

climate.watering: Wheat requires moderate water during the growing season, especially during germination and flowering stages. Over-watering can lead to diseases like rust.

symptoms: Small, round, orange-brown pustules on the upper side of leaves.
Yellowing and chlorosis around the lesions.
Premature leaf death and reduced photosynthetic capacity.
Stunting of plant growth and lower yield potential.

background.cause: Fungal disease caused by *Puccinia triticina*, affecting wheat plants by producing orange-brown pustules on leaves.
background.spread_by: Wind, rain, and infected plant material.

cure: Apply fungicides like Tebuconazole or Propiconazole to control the rust.
Remove and destroy infected plants and plant debris.
Use resistant wheat varieties to minimize the impact of the disease.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers, especially nitrogen, to support plant health and increase resistance to diseases.
prevention: Practice crop rotation to reduce pathogen buildup in the soil.
Control the spread of rust by spraying with fungicides as soon as symptoms appear.

symptoms: Yellow streaks or lines on the leaves, often along the veins.
Light yellow or orange pustules on the underside of leaves.
Premature leaf senescence and reduced grain fill.
Infected plants show stunted growth, lower yield, and poor quality grain.

background.cause: Fungal disease caused by *Puccinia striiformis f.sp. tritici*, characterized by yellow streaks or lines on wheat leaves.

cure: Use fungicides like Azoxystrobin or Chlorothalonil to control the rust.
Remove infected plants and surrounding debris to reduce pathogen spread.
Adopt resistant wheat varieties where available.
diseases.fertilizers: Use fertilizers rich in nitrogen and potassium to support plant growth and reduce susceptibility to disease.
prevention: Plant resistant wheat varieties or those with partial resistance.
Practice crop rotation to reduce rust pathogen pressure.
Avoid planting wheat in fields previously infected with yellow rust.

preventive_practices: Use disease-resistant wheat varieties that are tolerant to rust diseases.
Regularly monitor the crop for early signs of rust and apply fungicides at the first sign of infection.
Practice crop rotation to reduce the buildup of rust spores in the soil.
Use certified disease-free seeds and avoid using seeds from infected plants.
Ensure proper field sanitation by removing plant residues after harvest to limit the spread of the disease.
